item.question: Which of the following is a characteristic property of an LDAP directory?
item.hint: LDAP is designed as a lightweight version of the X.500 Directory Access Protocol. X.500 DAP was designed to store e-mail adresses and provide name lookup facilities in a structural manner. However, nowadays LDAP is used to store a lot more information, e.g. computer inventory, employee information, authorisation information, etc. etc.

item.question:
You want to search an LDAP directory for all users under the age of 25.
The age of the users is stored in the attribute type age.
Which of the following commands will provide you with this information?
item.hint: LDAP does not support a less-than or greater-than filter-operator.

item.question: When designing your directory structure (namespace) which of the following is true?
item.choice: There may be no loops in your directory structure.
The Relative Distinguished Name has to be unique among all siblings at the same level.
You may use any attribute type at any level of the directory structure.
You cannot replicate part of your directory structure.
item.correct_answer: There may be no loops in your directory structure.
The Relative Distinguished Name has to be unique among all siblings at the same level.

item.question: What are Object Identifiers (OID) used for?
item.choice: To distinguish different LDAP server implementations
To label office inventory when you use LDAP to manage your office inventory
item.hint: An OID (Object Identifier) is a globally unique number that identifies objects. Assignment of OIDs is managed by IANA.

item.question: Which of the following is true considering the ACL in above exhibit.
item.choice: The LDAP directory server itself may authenticate
Everyone is denied access to the attribute <font face="monospace">userPassword</font>
Users may change their own password stored in <font face="monospace">userPassword</font>
item.correct_answer: Users may change their own password stored in <font face="monospace">userPassword</font>
item.hint: By default the kind of access is cumulative. This means that a higher access privilege includes lower access privileges as well. Unless an equal sign preceds the access privilege. In that case only the specified privileges count.
